## fa'afafine
 
 <i>n.</i> Samoan transvestite or cross-dresser [ORIGIN: Samoan]

>  <i>A Frigate Bird Sings</i> follows the struggle of a fa'afafine.. trying to understand and redefine her contribution to her Samoan family, now living in New Zealand. "It's an extremely delicate subject.. particularly among older Polynesians, because in New Zealand the fa'afafine are part of the gay scene; they've become much more visible and upfront about something that in Samoa is an accepted part of their culture. I think some Polynesians feel that the fa'afafine have become an embarrassment to who we are." <i>(Oct 19, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40</i>)

## face
 
 <i>n.</i> [An extended mining use (cf. OED2 20 b. end of a tunnel or stope at which work is progressing) transf. to bushfalling and gumdigging.] of a tunnel, slope, at which work is progressing'; perhaps influenced by mining

## face cut
 
 <i>n.</i> The first piece of timber sawn from a log on the breaking-down bench. [Forestry. Transf. use of face = surface. Recorded earliest in NZ.]

>  <b>BAINES</b> Suppose a piece of timber - a flitch nine inches by twenty-four and sixteen feet long - is on the carriage, and that we intend cutting nine by three-quarter boards. After taking off a `face' cut, setting the gauger rollers, and placing the flitch in position, the man at the head starts the machinery. `Kreash,' says the saw. and in twelve seconds she is out at the other end. The man at the `tail' at that instant reverses the motion of the table, which gigs back. <i>(1874,Edward Crewe,180</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> So far we had asked for `facecuts', the first slices off the logs with the bark adhering ... <i>(1950,My First 80 Years,105</i>) [NOTES: [c1890-1900]]

>  <b>WILSON</b> There were good boards among these facecuts which today would be classed as O.B. <i>(1955,Land of My Children,28</i>)

## fan
 
 <i>n.</i> A deposit, fan- or cone-shaped, of alluvial shingle brought down when a river is in flood; a similar deposit or slip on a hillside. [See 1846 cit. Also called alluvial fan, gravel fan, shingle fan.]

>  <b>HAAST</b> ... Dr Hector and myself, in drawing up a synopsis of the geological formations of New Zealand, have adopted for the formation of those subaerial accumulations the expression `Fan', for those of regular watercourses; and of `Half-cone', for those of intermittent mountain torrents, and we shall for the future use these two expressions. <i>(1864,Report on the Formation of the Canterbury Plains,19</i>)

>  In previous publications (amongst others, `Report ... Canterbury Plains, 1864' page 22 et seq) I have shown how in post-pliocene times from the material brought down by the enormous glacier torrents forming huge shingle fans at the foot of the glaciers, two bars were thrown across the sea; <i>(1875,TrNZI,7/55</i>)

>  Content with our day's walk, we camped on the large fan of Pass Creek. <i>(1885,TrNZI,17/352</i>) [NOTES: (Parke)]

>  [The Canterbury Plains] have been formed by the overlapping fans of great glacier streams ... <i>(1909,TrNZI,40/38</i>) [NOTES: (Speight)]

>  <b>SPEIGHT</b> One word now universally accepted in geological literature, viz., `fan', was first used by [Haast]. <i>(1927,Natural History of Canterbury,62</i>)

>  Fan: Hill creeks in Canterbury and Otago bring a lot of shingle down with them when they are in flood. On steep hillsides this shingle shingle spreads on each side of the creek, narrow at the top and wide at the bottom. This natural feature is called a fan. In time tussocks grow over the shingle and some large fans of 500 to 1000 or more acres contain very good land. (C.) <i>(Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

>  <b>DAWSON</b> In the Cook Strait area the grey-leaved spaniard (<i>Aciphylla squarrosa</i>) is also a common plant on fans. <i>(1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,158</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>n.</i> a group of leaves, or clump, of the NZ flax growing in the shape of a fan.

## fantail
 
 <i>n.</i> A handsome flycatcher of the New Zealand bush. Pre-settlement North Island writers prefer piwaka(waka) (Markham 1834, Yate 1835); early more-or-less scientific writers prefer fantailed (less often fantail) flycatcher, or merely flycatcher; fantail as a popular name is attested in 1845 (1854) (Wellington), 1851 (Taranaki) and sanctioned by Buller (1873 (1888)). Also called piwakawaka, tiwakawaka, shortened from fantail(ed) flycatcher, <i>Rhipidura flabellifera</i>, Pied or North Island Fantail, =piwakawaka; and <i>R. fuliginosa</i>, Black or South Island Fantail, =tiwaiwaka.

>  <b>FORSTER</b> ... Pohebirds, Fantails, Thrushes, Mocking birds, Yellowheads & various other birds inhabit these impenetrable Forests. <i>(May 13, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/278</i>)

>  <b>GOLDER</b> ... fantail ... <i>(1845,Pigeon's Parliament,37</i>)

>  <b>LEICHHARDT</b> `We also observed the..fantailed fly-catcher (<i>Rhipidura</i>).' <i>(1847,Journal,ii/80</i>)

>  There is plenty to be said about the parrots and the owls, and the beautiful little fantails. <i>(Jun 15, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/96,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

>  <b>MACKIE</b> Strolling in the bush adjoining our inn, observed the native pigeon a large and beautiful bird ... The lively and elegant little fan tail was continually flitting about me spreading and erecting its tail. <i>(Apr 1, 1853,Traveller under Concern,96,1973 ed.</i>)

>  <b>DRURY</b> BIRDS MET WITH IN PELORUS ... Stilts - two kinds, called Toria by natives. Flycatchers and Fantails. <i>(1855,Sailing Directions,66</i>)

>  <i>(1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/645</i>)

>  Fantail ... the pied Flycatcher. <i>(1868,TrNZI</i>) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

>  Rhipidura flabellifera. Piwaka-waka. Fantail. Common. <i>Ibid.</i> I 1/164 The other birds ... were ... the Fan-tail (<i>Rhipidura flabellifera</i>, the Ground-lark (<i>Anthus Novae Zelandiae</i>), the New Zealand Titmouse (<i>Certhiparus Novae Zelandiae</i>) ... <i>(1869,TrNZI,1/160</i>) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

>  RHIPIDURA FLABELLIFERA, Gml. Piwakawaka. Fan-tail. The pied Flycatcher seems to prefer proximity to water in selecting its nesting- place ... <i>(1870,TrNZI,2/63</i>) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>Piiwakawaka<i>, n. <i>rhipidura flabellifera</i>, or<i> fantail</i>; a bird. <i>(1871,Dictionary of the Maori Language,117,3rd ed.</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> ... a fantail <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,232</i>)

The New Zealand species are. -->Black F.- <i>Rhipidura fuliginosa</i>, Sparrm. (Tiwaiwaka). -->Pied F.- <i>R. flabellifera</i>, Gmel. (Piwakawa). In Tasmania, the <i>R. diemenensis</i> is called the Cranky Fantail, because of its antics. <i>(1898,Austral English,141</i>)

>  Opposition parties call the [emissions research] levy a "flatulence" or "fart" tax... ACT MP Gerry Eckhoff, who is touring New Zealand in a "fart tax bus", urged farmers to stand firm against the Government's "back door attempt to save face." <i>(Aug 30, 2003,Dominion Post,A5</i>)

>  The Government has abandoned its plans for a flatulence tax in the face of fierce farmer opposition and international derision... "Animal fart tax puts wind up New Zealand farmers," the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation said on its website. "Farmers raise stink over New Zealand fart tax," said <i>The Guardian</i> newspaper in Britain. <i>(Oct 17, 2003,Dominion Post,A1</i>)

>  The access issue does not lend itself to a mocking "fart tax" label that brought them the support of urban dwellers and the media. <i>(Nov 27, 2004,Dominion Post,A9</i>)

>  The battle over perceptions was lost when the Government was forced to fight a scatological, absurd-sounding levy - "the fart tax" - which incidentally gave the rest of the world a laugh at our expense. <i>(Oct 23, 2003,Dominion Post,C2</i>)

>  We don't want no fart tax, no bloody way. <i>(Sep 20, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7</i>)

>  The very term "flatulence tax" is controversial; the Government says it is not a tax but a research levy; environmental groups believe the farming lobby deliberately uses terms such as "fart tax" to make the charge sound more ludicrous. <i>(Jul 26, 2003,Dominion Post,F2</i>)

## fascia
 
 <i>n.</i> a board under the edge of the roof at the eaves, to support spouting and divert water away from the wall [Jim Cameron writes : NSOD gives "a horizontal band of wood etc. esp as used in an architrave" [i.e. a part surrounding a door or window"]. >  <b>McNAB</b> [Whalers] were under the impression that ... they would have no further labour ... than to fasten to whales alongside, cut in, try out, stow away without intermission, until their cargoes would be completed. <i>(1913,Old Whaling Days,154</i>) [NOTES: >1836 Capt. Greene Report in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 154]

>  Two Boats out fastened to a Whale the Iron drew and we lost her <i>Ibid.</i> 73 Saw a large Whale was in chase best part of the day, but she was so Galeyed we had no chance of fastening. <i>(Apr 28, 1838,Piraki Log,71</i>)

>  <b>GRADY</b> Fasten - To successfully harpoon a whale. <i>(1982,Perano Whalers,226</i>)

## feed
 
 <i>v.</i> To lay out rabbit-food (on a block), to accustom rabbits to the same food as a poison-bait. [rabbiters']

>  <b>MILLER</b> One professional poacher I heard of used to watch a rabbiter `feed' his block - that is, to cut up pieces of carrot along the intended poison lines so that the rabbits would get used to the feed before the strychnine was applied - and then, after two feeds, he would step in one night ahead of the rabbiter with his own poison and make a kill. <i>(1946,There Was Gold,130</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> The rabbits are then `fed'. Carrots, cut with a knife, or minced, or even cut up in a box with a spade, are scattered along the furrow, or `line'. ...The feeding is usually done three times, and the rabbits eat up the carrot each time. On the fourth night the poison is laid ... <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,60</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> The area to be poisoned is first `fed' twice with straight oats and then poisoned. <i>(1973,Big Country,56</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a solid, heavy meal (modern coll, esp. a restaurant or hash-house fried meal). [(usu. a feed) 1984 16-17 F E10 Pakuranga Coll. 22B FEED [F5M8] -->1984 14 F E122Wgton Girls C. 22B]

>  <b>HARGREAVES</b> He still comes down to the wharf occasionally to burgle a feed of dabs. <i>(1998,On the Next Tide,64</i>)

>  <b>FERGUSON</b> And he in less than half-an-hour/ Had such a pile of Johnnie-cake,/ That on the embers he did bake/ ... And went down with a relish high,/ With steaming tea and liver fry; -/ And that by men [sc. shepherds] so much in need/ Was well pronounced `a glorious feed'. <i>(1883,Castle Gay,177</i>)

>  I hated it there. My first time I hid in the dunny for about an hour. But she usually gave me a good feed - savs or snarlers, and sometimes a whole chip of strawberries. And fizzy drink instead of cordial. <i>(1988,University Entrance Board Bursaries Exam,6</i>)

## feed budget

For (pioneer) fence types see basket-fence, bush-fence, ditch and bank fence, ditch and sod fence, dog-leg(ged) fence, hedge and ditch, log-fence, log and stake, paling-fence, pig-fence, picket-fence, post and rail, post and wire, post and stake, rail-fence, ring-fence, scrub-fence, seven-wire, snow-fence, sod-fence, stab-fence, stake-fence, stone fence, stub-fence stud-fence, taiepa (fence), wattle fence, wire fence. See also rabbit (-proof). Cf. fencing terms dropper, (spinning-)jenny, standard, strainer, stringer, waratah. [AND has entry at NETTING FENCE. chk DNZE at N] [[Of particular relevance to NZ pioneer farming history. `Bad fences make bad neighbours.' cf OED2 5.]]

## Fencibles
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>G. GRAHAME</b> Civilian labour continuing scarce, ... I have been compelled to employ [natives] at all kinds of work, - in rafting timber for the erection of cottages for the New Zealand Fencibles. <i>(Sep 23, 1847,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1847 Nov 23 Letter (Auckland) in 1849 Power Sketches in NZ 283]

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> During the year 1847, ... about 500 veteran out-pensioners, constituted into a regiment of New Zealand Fencibles, have been sent to Auckland at public expense, with their wives and families; ... <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,376</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> The corps known as the Royal New Zealand Fencibles, ... was a body of veteran soldiers converted into military settlers, established through Governor Grey's efforts as a protection for the southern frontier of the Auckland Settlement. It consisted of discharged British soldiers, about three-fourths of them pensioners, and all men of approved character and physique. The corps was enrolled in England in 1847. The term of service in New Zealand was to be seven years (most of the soldiers became permanent settlers); ... on arrival in the colony each Fencible was given possession of a two-roomed cottage and an acre of land ... The members of the corps were required to attend six days' drill in the spring and six in autumn, and to attend church parade every Sunday, fully armed, for inspection. ... The settlements in which the pensioners were established were Onehunga, Otahuhu, [451] Panmure, and Howick; these places were practically founded as villages by the Fencibles. <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,1/450</i>)

>  <b>NORRIS</b> After Hone Heke's rebellion ... in 1845, military settlements to provide a bulwark between Auckland and the Maoris had been established, at Onehunga, Otahuhu, Howick and Panmure. These settlers were military pensioners, called `Fencibles' and their villages were to form a ring of husbandsmen trained to the use of arms; a self-supporting guard. <i>(1963,Armed Settlers,36</i>)

>  <b>BUCKLEY</b> The first families [of military settlers] reached Auckland in August 1847 on the Ramilies from Tilbury. ... Known as the `Fencibles' - soldiers liable only for home service - they were provided with a house and land at the outpost settlements. <i>(1983,Of Toffs and Toilers,143</i>)

>  <b>CRESSWELL</b> The Fencibles were pensioners from various regiments of the British Army, all of whom had seen over 20 years of active service in India, China, Afghanistan, or other countries. Although no longer fit for the rigours of overseas campaigns, they were all under 48 years of age, of good physique and character, and quite fit for the garrison duty which was theirs when they came to New Zealand in the years 1847-8; a few following in 1852. <i>(1976,MOTAT,86</i>)

>  The vibrant history of the fencibles and their Maori neighbours is very much alive at the village... <i>(Jan 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 67/14</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>WALLACE</b> <i>Fern crushing</i>. Of the fern country, that upon a limestone formation is the best and the least expensive to break in. <i>Ibid.</i> 245 <i>Cattle</i> [bold] are required for jungle or fern-crushing ... <i>(1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,230</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> The first care of the settler was to increase his area of grass by the operation known through Hawke's Bay as `fern-crushing' or `fern-grinding,' - words ominous of the part played by the unfortunate sheep, and which will be described later. It is sufficient now to state that after fire had cleared the tangled bracken growth, the ground was surface-sown and kept clear by browsing sheep. As the greatest growth of fern took place during late spring, it was then impossible to have too many sheep. Every squatter in Hawke's Bay was in the 'eighties `fern-grinding,' so that in those times sheep could not be bought at that season of the year. The result was that every sheep likely to survive the winter was kept, however old and however fleeced. It was at least a pair of jaws, a beast that could bite bracken. <i>(1926,Tutira,134</i>)

>  <b>BELSHAW</b> Hence beef-cattle are used for `fern-crushing', that is, for keeping in check the undesirable second growth of bracken fern over large areas of the North Island hills. <i>(1947,New Zealand (various authors/titles),40</i>) [NOTES: 1947 Clark in Belshaw New Zealand 40]

>  <b>RICKARD</b> An operation that seems to have been peculiar to the hill country of Hawke's Bay was the strenuous one known as fern-crushing. [ref. Guthrie-Smith <i>Tutira</i>.] <i>(1967,Strangers in the Wilderness,47</i>)

>  <b>HUNT</b> But there were no cattle coming up to listen. ... They'd been in there fern crushing, hundreds of acres of bracken. Men'd just walked off that land in the slump but those cattle were breaking it all in again. <i>(1981,Speaking a Silence,46</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) using stock or machinery to crush bracken fern prior to burning and seeding for pasture [or to check its secondary growth.]

>  <b>WALLACE</b> Fern-crushing. Of the fern country, that upon a limestone formation is the best and the least expensive to break in. <i>(1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,230</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> The first care of the settler was to increase his area of grass by the operation known through Hawke's Bay as fern-crushing or fern-grinding ... <i>(1921,Tutira,134</i>)

>  Fern crushing is at times severe on stock, and they should not be left on too long ... <i>(Jul 15, 1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,8</i>)

>  <b>CUMBERLAND</b> Another really extensive cultural practice that modified the New Zealand landscape was 'fern-crushing' - the replacement at the cost of continued effort, of the natural Pteridium (bracken fern) heath with artificial grassland. <i>(1944,Soil Erosion in New Zealand,161</i>)

>  <b>MCCASKILL</b> Another really extensive cultural practice that modified the New Zealand landscape was fern-crushing. <i>(1973,Hold This Land,5</i>)

>  When Miss Jessie Pope met the men of the Fernleaf Forces, their good fortune was not exclusively hers. <i>(Mar 14, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/14 : 40</i>)

>  What strikes me most about the Fernleaf crowd is their beautiful humility respecting the merits of their own country. <i>(Jan 17, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,I/10 : 223</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> A New Zealander, esp. a NZ soldier in WW1. [(?obsolesc. mainly pl)]

>  <b>FRASER & GIBBONS</b> <i>FERNLEAVES, THE</i>: A familiar term for the New Zealanders. (From the New Zealand badge). <i>(1925,Soldier and Sailor Words,93</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... <i>mad money</i>, return fare, it being very generally believed by the New Zealand troops (<i>Fernleaves</i> or, as they preferred to call themselves, <i>Diggers</i>) that every English girl infallibly carried her return fare in case her soldier friend became <i>mad</i>, i.e., acted with excessive freedom of manner; <i>(1935,Slang Today,285</i>) [NOTES: 1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 285]

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Fernleaves</i>. New Zealanders; esp. N.Z. soldiers: military coll: 1915. F. & Gibbons. Ex the badge of the N.Z. soldiers. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,271</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> New Zealanders were <i>Fernleaves</i> and <i>Kiwis</i> [to Australians]. <i>(1941,NZ Slang,49</i>)

>  <b>SOLJAK</b> The kiwi, like the fernleaf, is now a New Zealand national emblem and provided the name by which Dominion servicemen were popularly known during the war. (The term `Anzac' correctly applies to veterans of World War I.) Appropriately enough, the nickname `kiwi' has also been applied to grounded airmen throughout the Allied air forces. <i>(1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),8</i>)

>  <b>PUGSLEY</b> Indeed it was as New Zealanders that other nationalities identified us [in WW1], not as `Otago' or the `Canterbury boys' but as `Fernleaves' or `New Zealanders' and it made sense to do so ourselves. ... [fn] `Fernleaf' and `Fernleaves' - the slang term for New Zealanders. `Kiwi' was not used. According to Brophy and Partridge in <i>The Long Trail</i>, Kiwi meant a ground-duty air force man. A `Kiwi King' was any officer fussy about spit and polish, derived from the brand of Kiwi shoe polish. <i>(1984,Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story,13 and fn</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>Fernleaf</i> New Zealander, from the badge worn by WWI soldiers; replaced by `Kiwi'. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,45</i>)

>  Call them "Cornstalks" or "Fernleaves" - all out for a fight - But don't call them Anzacs for that isn't right. <i>(Nov 15, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/6 : 127</i>)

>  With these words, Wiri Fernleaf executed a few steps of the Highland fling on the duck-walk. <i>(Feb 14, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,I/12 : 282</i>)

>  With his father, a civil engineer, he [William Hughes Field] made the original exploration of "Field's Track" between Wanganui and the Karioi plains. <i>(Dec 14, 1944,Dominion,6</i>)

>  Long after those of us who knew him personally have passed away, [his name] will be known to a much wider section of the public - to travellers between Palmerston North and the Capital city -because of "Field's Express." <i>Ibid 87 </i> I can recall the fight he put up for the train we now refer to as "Field's Express." <i>(1945,NZ Parliamentary Debates,CCLXVIII/86</i>)

This interesting fish has a number of other vernacular names, such as File-fish, and all with a bearing on its construction. The name Leather-Jacket is due to the fancied resemblance to a North American lumber jacket, not unlike the dark brown coloured jumpers used by hikers. The word rough is attached to the name Leather Jacket by fishermen, because the scales are furnished with sharp points which make the skin so rough that one's fingers cannot be rubbed freely in a direction from tail to head without losing part of one's skin, hence the name File-fish. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,374,2nd ed. ed.</i>)

>  <b>DOOGUE & MORELAND</b> ROUGH LEATHERJACKET ... <i>Other names: Novodon convexirostris</i>; triggerfish and filefish are used, but should rightly be given to a family of tropical fishes of similar appearance to our leatherjackets; kokiri (Maori). <i>(1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,293</i>)

>  <b>SORENSON</b> LEATHERJACKET (a) Scientific name: <i>Navodon scaber</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Creamfish (fillets); Leatherjacket. (c) Other common names: Triggerfish; Filefish. ## finder
 
 <i>n.</i> a pig dog trained to find wild pigs. Cf holder.

>  Pig-dog types are many ... The writer's [J.P.Lewin's] considered classification is straight finders, straight bailers, straight holders and straight killers. ... Inside it we have finder-bailers; bailer-holders; finder-bailer-holders; bailer-holder-killers and holder-killers. <i>(Dec 1951,Here & Now,15</i>)

There's the wind finder and the track finder. The wind finder will take a pig first ... If you've got a good wind finder with you and you're working the right way into the wind, if there's a pig lying anywhere up to 1000 or 1500 yards away he'll be away like a shot ... With a track finder the pig might be on the move and he'll leave a lot of scent on the undergrowth. The dog will immediately pick that up and he'll stick his nose on the ground ... He'll tail off after the pig and stop him some way, nip him in the leg or somewhere else. <i>(Apr 19, 1962,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5</i>) [NOTES: (Interview Murphy/Crump)]

The use of the military term `Echelon' in the sense of first, second or third echelon has puzzled many people. >  The last remarks contained in the report with regard to the want of easy access to the back country, and the consequent unfair pressure of the difficulties upon the first settler who endeavours to open up the country, are perfectly just, and the remedy proposed is certainly a practicable one; the only difficulty is the providing of funds, but the work ought to be done. <i>(Jan 30, 1858,Otago Witness,4</i>)

>  Mr. Duke entered the Wararapa [sic] last week with about forty head of cattle. Mr. Duke is the first settler in that fine district. <i>(Apr 24, 1844,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3</i>)

>  Wednesday last being the 22nd Anniversary of the arrival of the first settlers in Port Nicholson, was observed as a general holiday; and the Government Offices, Banks and other places of business were closed. <i>(Jan 24, 1862,Wellington Independent,2</i>)

>  The honourable member for Wairarapa (Mr Bunny) had stated that the reason Wellington had not advanced as rapidly as the other Provinces was because there were too many educated men among its early settlers, and that these men either could not or would not work. Now he (Mr Buckland) had resided in Wellington for some months immediately after the arrival of its first settlers, and his impression was that there was a willingness and desire to work among all classes . <i>(Sep 28, 1871,Otago Daily Times,5</i>)

>  LAKES WANAKA AND HAWEA .. The first settler who made his habited [sic] in this terra incognita was the late Mr Henry Norman, who came, here as the manager of a station for a Wellington firm of squatters in February, 1859. <i>(Apr 9, 1881,Otago Witness,9</i>)

>  Now that there is a town of 1000 or more inhabitants within a few miles of the Knapdale homestead, a railway within three or four miles, and good roads all round the estate, it is not easy to imagine the difficulties and dangers that its first settler had to undergo - no neighbour for miles; no practising doctor for 100 miles, no help or comfort in any way whatever. <i>(Aug 14, 1890,Otago Witness,19</i>)

>  Then came the first settlers, men of energy and strong of heart, who rushed their way through many difficulties. <i>(Jul 3, 1923,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4</i>)

## firsts
 
 <i>n.</i> [(child marble players')]

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,175</i>)

## firsts and lasts
 
 <i>phr.</i> [(marble term)]

## fiscal envelope
 
 <i>n.</i> a Government limitation on the total amount of money payable to Maori claimants under the Treaty of Waitangi settlements [Surfacing again in 1996 as a specific term for Maori refunds]

>  Such is the opposition to the proposals, some believe the issue could be more heated than the "fiscal envelope" hui of the mid-1990s, the last time Maori and the Crown met head on... The fiscal envelope was the term given to the then-National Government's plan to limit Treaty settlements. It was eventually dumped. <i>(Aug 29, 2003,Dominion Post,B5</i>)

>  To Smith it was simply a classic piece of radical publicity seeking, designed to focus debate on the government's now-famous "fiscal envelope". which would settle all Treaty claims for $1 billion in 10 years. <i>(Jan 14, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33</i>)

>  The fiscal envelope is like Selwyn Toogood's old quiz show, except it's called 'Money <i>and</i> the Bag.' <i>(May 13, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26</i>)

>  Maori expectations of big financial settlements soon rose so rapidly that Jim Bolger's ministry introduced the "fiscal envelope", limiting them to $1 billion. <i>(May 1, 2002,Dominion,10</i>)

>  The Maori leaders at those huis in the early 1990s conveyed to Parliament such strong messages as their opposition to the billion-dollar fiscal envelope. <i>(Mar 12, 2001,Dominion,2</i>)

>  Cabinet papers obtained by The Evening Post confirm that settlement payments are going to blow out well beyond the $1 billion cap - the so-called fiscal envelope - that the former National Government imposed in 1994. <i>(Jul 20, 2000,Evening Post,1</i>)

>  Moutoa might still never have happened without the galvanising spark of the fiscal envelope. <i>(Apr 22, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20</i>)

>  The Fiscal Envelope, what a lot of hooey! <i>(Feb 26, 1995,Sunday Star Times,C4</i>)

>  Bluntly, the fiscal envelope is a power struggle over who will control New Zealkand's resources. <i>(May 6, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14</i>)

>  Officially, the fiscal envelope - that sought to place a billion-dollar cap on Treaty settlements - is dead.... ## five per cent
 
 <i>n.</i> [Jim writes: Local & Historical. Several Wairarapa purchases of land from Maori in the Grey period had clauses providing that five percent of the profits of the resale of the land was to be set aside for school, flour mills, etc. for the benefit of Maori. This promise was never full honoured and was a source of Maori grievance thereafter. The <i>(Wairapapa) five percents</i> are the subject of a current application to the Waitangi Tribunal (<i>Wairarapa Times-Age</i> 6/4/00).] (See [Wellington Tenths](../W#wellington-tenths))

>  <b>BAGNALL</b> The Tauwharenikau block purchase as well as Tuhitarata, was completed with the aid of a provision peculiar to the Wairarapa, the requirement that five per cent of the subsequent return from land sales should be paid back to the Maori vendors.<i>Ibid.</i> 204 More culpable was the with-holding of moneys from the five per cents... Some members of Government expected that the mill would be erected from the 'five per cents' the proceeds from sales in certain designated blocks, for which.. the construction of flour mills was an explicit objective. <i>(1976,Wairarapa : An Historical Excursion,102</i>)

## flannel-leaf
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Verbascum thapsus</i>, Aaron's rod, golden rod, mullein, native tobacco, tobacco plant, velvet, wooly mullein (See [mullein](../M#mullein))

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> FLANNEL LEAF (<i>Verbascum thapsus</i>) is commonly called mullein in England, and is frequently so called here as well. Its commonest local name is probably tobacco plant, or native tobacco, a name for which there is no justification in either appearance or use. Velvet mullein, woolly mullein, golden rod, and Aaron's rod are other appellations, but flannel leaf, one of the common sheep-station names is both descriptive and distinctive. The plant is found in dry soil and river beds ... in both islands. <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,155,1967 ed.</i>)

>  VERBASCUM THAPSUS, a weed of poor land has many popular names. In New Zealand it is called native tobacco, velvet, flannel leaf and golden rod. <i>(Nov 22, 1974,Dominion,5</i>)

>  <b>ELL</b> The Woolly Mullein is often known in New Zealand as flannel-leaf for its leaves have a woolly feel to them. <i>(1983,Wildflowers and Weeds,14</i>)

## flapjack

 <i>n.</i> a seaweed

>  <b>MARTIN</b> A little lower down where the seaweeds are permanently submerged we have such plants as the GRAPELET, the WIRE- WEED, and OX-TONGUE; the FLAP-JACK and GIRDLE WEEDS. In rather deeper water ... we have the (<i>Lessonia</i>) and the OARWEED, the GRAPEWEED, and numerous representatives of the red algae. <i>Ibid./</i> Flora 14 The commonest of the four species is (<i>C[arpophyllum] maschalocarpum</i>) which has been designated by the apt and appropriate name of FLAP-JACK from the habit of the plant in swaying first in one direction and then the other as the water enters or recedes from the surge channels between tidal rocks. <i>(1961,Flora NZ,5,1929 ed.</i>)

## flash note
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HARGREAVES</b> The [Governor Fitzroy's (1844)] Debentures, popularly known as `government rags', were given various nicknames such as assignats, `shinplasters', and `flash notes'. All these terms had reference to worthless paper money, some of which had been issued in the past. Assignats was the name given to large amounts of paper money issued in France during the French Revolution, but which depreciated to such as extent to be almost worthless. `Shinplasters'--sometimes written `skinplasters'--had its origin in North America, and again referred to depreciated paper money, while `flash notes' was a popular term in use for any counterfeit money or worthless forged paper money. <i>(1972,From Beads to Banknotes,40</i>)

Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,11</i>)

## flounder
 
 <i>v.</i> go floundering



 
 <i>n.</i> any of various flatfish with a large mouth and both eyes usually occurring on the left side of the head; aka patiki [see also greenback (flounder) 1770 B.J. 2/8 see cit. for SOLE]

>  <b>POLACK</b> Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called <i>para</i>[as-acute] <i>paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i>mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i>mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn</i>)

>  (Queen Charlotte Sound) We observ'd already that the principal fish caught by the seyne were Mullets [ed. fn Aldrichetta forsteri.] and Elephant fish [ed. fn Callarhyncus milli.] & a few soles [ed. fn Peltorhamphus novaeseelandiae.] and flounders, [ed.fn Rhombosalea spp.] but those which the Indians mostly supply'd us with are a sort of sea Bream of a silver colour with a black spot on the neck, [ed. fn Tarakihi, ...] ... <i>(1967,Cook's Journals,3/807</i>) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/807]

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> Fish of all sorts and sizes abound on every part of the sea-coast. The only sorts similar to ours are the Conger-eel, Sole, Plaice, and Flounder. <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,160</i>)

>  English Name Native Name ... ... Flounder Patiki ... ... <i>(1849,NZ Journal,(Vol. IX) 125</i>) [NOTES: (quoting Anglo Maori Warder Oct 5)]

>  <b>POWER</b> The flounders are a splendid fish, the finest of their tribe; spearing them by torchlight is an excellent sport. <i>(1849,Sketches in NZ,77</i>)

>  Many ... varieties of sea-fish are caught round the coast, such as barracouta, groper, rock-cod, ling, flounders, soles, gar-fish, and others, all which are plentiful; ... <i>(1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The,32</i>)

>  <b>HUTTON</b> 83. <i>RHOMBOSOLEA MONOPUS</i>. Gunth. Flounder. Patiki. <i>(1872,Fishes,51</i>)

>  That no flounders should be sold under nine inches long; no red cod under ten inches; no mullet under nine inches; and no garfish under fourteen inches -... <i>(1879,TrNZI,11/381</i>) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

>  <b>SHERRIN</b> <i>Rhombosolea monopus</i> Gunther Patiki, or Flounder <i>(1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,304</i>)

>  Catlin's River - Mullet (sea), flounders, sole, sardines <i>(1892,TrNZI,24/204</i>) [NOTES: (Thomson) 20]

>  Flounder or Patiki (<i>Rhombosolea monopus</i>). Probably the yellow-belly (R. leporina)is included among the returns. <i>(1892,TrNZI,24/213</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> ~ The Flounders in Australia are - In Sydney, <i>Pseudorhombus russeli</i>, Gray; in Melbourne, <i>Rhombosolea vistoria</i>, Castln.; in New Zealand and Tasmania, <i>R. monopus</i>, Gunth. Maori name, Patiki; family Pleuronectida. They are all excellent eating. <i>(1898,Austral English,148</i>)

>  `Patiki (flounder).are in the market all the year.' - <i>(1876,TrNZI,9/487</i>) [NOTES: Thomson]

>  In other parts king-fish in abundance, red cod, soles, and flounders were found, and large numbers of elephant-fish, gurnard, and schnapper, ... <i>(1901,TrNZI,33/574</i>)

>  <b>DRUMMOND & HUTTON</b> Among the flat-fish, there are three or four different varieties of flounders, but they are usually all clubbed together. <i>(1902,Nature in NZ,73</i>)

>  <b>HAMILTON</b> ... with the following results: 581 eels (from 1ft. to 4ft. in length); 8 dozen flounders, of various sizes, large numbers of aua, or kataka (mullet); about 70lb. or 70lb. weight of pilchard, or mohimohi; a few snapper and kahawai; hundreds of red cod and rarii; and a number of kokopu or rawaru. <i>(1908,Fishing and Sea-Foods,64</i>)

Natural History of Canterbury 201]

(b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder. <i>(1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,24</i>)

## fly boy
 
 <i>n.</i> [flaxmilling]

>  <b>CARR</b> When the flax arrives at the mill it is weighed and credited to the cutter. The `bench loader' then takes two or three bundles and puts them in a barrel (heavy end down). He then takes the longest leaves and places them on a bench convenient to the `feeder'. ...[44] The `feeder' takes each blade separately and places the butt end into the `stripper' which takes the green outer covering off. ... The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. The latter, with a motion like cracking a whip, gets rid of as much rubbish as possible, after which he places the hank handy for the `washer'. ## flying gurnard
 
 <i>n.</i> [? An obs or N. Hemisphere name - check;]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Gurnet ... [Gurnard </i>cross-referenced to <i>Gurnet</i>] The species of <i>Trigla</i> found in British waters, called <i>Gurnards</i> are of the family of <i>Cottidae</i>. The word <i>Gurnet</i> is an obsolete or provincial form of <i>Gurnard</i>, revived in Australia, and applied to the fish <i>Centropogon scorpaenoides</i>, Guich., family Scorpaenidae. The original word <i>Gurnard</i> is retained in New Zealand, and applied to the new species <i>Trigla kumu</i> (kumu being the Maori name), family Cottidae. The <i>Flying Gurnet</i> is <i>Trigla polyommata</i>, Richards., found on all the Australian coasts from New South Wales to Western Australia, family <i>Cottidae</i>. It is a distinct species, not included in the British species. They have large pectoral fins, but are not known to possess the power of supporting themselves in the air like the `flying fish' which belong to other genera. Sir Fredk. McCoy says that <i>Sebastes Percoides</i>, Richards., is called Gurnet, or Garnet-perch, by the fishermen and dealers, as well as the more common <i>Neosebastes scorpaenoides</i>, Guich., and <i>Scorpaena panda</i>, Richards.] <i>Ibid.</i> 384 <i>Red Gurnet-Perch, n.</i> name given in Victoria to the fish <i>Sebastes percoides</i>, Richards., family <i>Scorpeaenidae</i>. It is also called <i>Poddy; Red Gurnard</i>, or <i>Gurnet</i>; and in New Zealand, <i>Pohuikaroa</i>. See <i>Perch</i> and <i>Gurnet</i>.] <i>(1898,Austral English</i>)

[In the Stout Collection copy, Victoria University Library, an early 19th C. or late 18th C. hand has added: `*Baracootas, a fish remarkably smooth about 7 or 8 foot long [dagger] Flying Gurnards, a flying fish, of a remarkable fine Gold Colour. >  Capital and Coast District Health Board has organised 11 public meetings as well as two hui with Maori and two fono with Pacific Islands people. <i>(Jun 28, 2001,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  In Samoa, kava is ceremoniously dispensed at the beginning of a fono, or meeting of village leaders. <i>(Sep 21, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30</i>)

>  Health issues of special concern to older Pacific people are discussed at fono held twice a year in Christchurch. The last fono...attracted over 50 people, including 33 older Pacific people (matua). <i>(Feb 2008,Keeping On,57:18</i>)

## foofoo valve
 
 <i>n.</i> [OED says foofoo (1826) is a kind of West African dough made from plantains. Partridge says a foofoo valve is 'a mythical "gadget" that's always blamed for any mechanical breakdown' but is RN slang dating back to around 1910. The phrase was common in the 1940s in NZ but was usually used in the figurative in the context of telling someone to take things steady - "Go easy or you'll bust your foofoo valve".]

>  He said that a good run cleared the foofoo valve and insisted whenever I fell or sprained my ankle that I got up and kept running. <i>(Sep 1998,North & South,61</i>)

## foot
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [fencing] to place a piece of wood or other solid material at the foot of a post to ensure it remains vertical.

>  <b>McKenny</b> ... When wiring on stones or iron to 'foot' posts it is preferable to fasten them on by passing the wire just through the hole ... <i>(1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,43</i>)

>  A reader from Warkworth, Northland, is seeking information on footing posts in a fence across swampy ground. Excepting in really steep dips, driven posts are seldom footed, though usually an extra long post is used in place of a footed post. <i>(Apr 11, 1968,NZ Farmer,17</i>)

>  <b>Crump</b> Then for three weeks they dug post - and strainer - holes, ran out wires, footed posts, blocked and stayed the angles, ... <i>(1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,126</i>)

>  <b>Mowat</b> This is a very slow fence to erect as there are so many posts to be footed. <i>(Oct 1, 1914,Alexander Mowat Diaries</i>)

>  The stay is also constructed of concrete "footed" by the concrete block shown in the right-hand bottom corner of Fig.3. <i>(Aug 15, 1939,NZ Journal of Agriculture,101</i>)

>  <b>Gascoigne</b> Now I maintain that your strainers should be footed so there's no chance of lift. Put in an eight-foot stay, block it firm and nothing will shift. Half the posts in the hollows here were never footed and they've lifted out and the sheep were walkin' through. <i>(1965,From the Top of a Hill,105</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a block of wood attached by wire to a post and buried with the post in the posthole; or some other device to stop the post being pulled out when the fence is strained

>  <b>R. GILBERD</b> Northland Posts in a dip are called `foot-posts' because they require `footing' to prevent their lifting as wires are strained. A `foot' is a buried block of wood fastened either to the post or to the wires. <i>(1951,Letter</i>)

>  <b>SHARPE</b> In the gullies you have to attach a `foot' to a post - a piece of timber or rock firmly slotted and wired into the bottom end. <i>(1962,Country Occasions,157</i>)

>  Ross prepared a `foot' to wedge into the base of the post. This was done with his well-used rammer. The `foot' was a solid piece of totara with a length of No8 wire stapled to it. <i>(Mar 21, 1981,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67</i>)

>  Foot: a block of wood attached by wire to a post and buried with the post in the posthole, or some other device to stop the post being pulled out when the fence is strained. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,28</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> super foot; a way of measuring timber

>  <b>DEMPSEY</b> He paid ten shillings per hundred feet for it, the best of heart rimu timber! <i>(1964,Little World of Stewart island,16</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [fencing] a piece of wood or other solid material buried at the foot of a post to ensure that it remains vertical.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> foot: attachment on the bottom of a post to prevent it from lifting. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,32</i>)

>  <b>MOWAT</b> I put in a foot under the fence between Killing Paddock and Front Face as sheep kept on getting through. <i>(1943,Alexander Mowat Diaries,8</i>)

>  <b>SHARPE</b> In the gullies you have to attach a 'foot' to a post - a piece of timber or rock firmly slotted and wired into the bottom end. <i>(1962,Country Occasions,157</i>)

>  Ross prepared a "foot" to wedge into the base of the post ... The "foot" was a solid piece of totara with a length of No8 wire stapled to it. <i>(Mar 21, 1981,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67</i>)

>  <b>MAF</b> Foot: a block of wood attached by wire to a post and buried with the post in a post-hole, or some other device to stop the post being pulled out when the fence is strained. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,28</i>)

## foot-rot
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a disease of cow's feet [known elsewhere as ''foul-in-the-foot''.]

>  Three of my cows are badly affected with foot-rot. <i>(Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,252</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to pare and treat the infected feet of sheep.

>  <b>MOWAT</b> Over to shed & footrotted the balance of our old stud ewes. <i>(Jan 12, 1941,Alexander Mowat Diaries</i>)

>  <b>BRABAZON</b> Got in 32 sheep from reserve. One dead one. Plucked him; footrotted and bluestoned 8. <i>(Jul 1, 1893,Brabazon Diaries</i>)

>  <b>MOWAT</b> Footrotted rams and put them in Toi paddock. <i>(Nov 19, 1915,Alexander Mowat Diaries,.</i>)

>  <b>PLUMMER</b> .. he and Donald between them cut gorse with me joining them at times when I wasn't footrotting ewes. <i>(1994,From Drover to Director,70</i>)

>  <b>BARDSLEY</b> I killed sheep, did the dagging, footrotted sheep and branded cattle. <i>(2000,Land Girls, The,148</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a disease of sheep's feet caused by a micro-organism Fuciformis nodosus, and often Spirochaeta penortha, resulting in lameness, and eventual starvation.

>  <b>EDGAR</b> Foot rot is a very common infection of sheep's feet, with as much as 30 per cent of a flock affected at a time. Two bacteria, Dichelobacter nodosus and Fusobacterium necrophorum, operating together cause foot rot. <i>(1959,NZ Farmers' Veterinary Guide,108</i>)

>  Romney Marsh are perhaps engaging more attention ... not liable to take foot-rot on the dampest bottoms. <i>(Nov 30, 1867,Weekly News,18</i>)

>  Foot-rot is a disease which has become exceedingly common and may cause considerable financial loss. <i>(Jul 15, 1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,4</i>)

>  <b>STEVENS</b> If any cases of foot-rot are found, the whole bought-in mob should be kept in isolation for a period sufficiently long to ensure that all have sound, uninfected feet. Not until the hill-country breeding farms eradicate foot-rot will its complete control on fat-lamb farms become a practical possibility. <i>(1958,Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry,119</i>)

## foot-rotting
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Jack was constantly on the farm, `mouthing ewes in the [136] yards', stooking with the children in the oats paddock, `foot-rotting the cull half-bred ewes', or `shifting sheep'. <i>(1985,Coldstream,135,1985 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1913 diary in Studholme Coldstream (1985) 135-136]

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Foot-rotting was a horribly monotonous job! <i>Ibid.</i> 116 116 Foot-rotting was a horribly monotonous job after one had been at it for weeks, and it was a great relief when the trouble disappeared for the time being. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,100,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <b>DARE</b> We did quite a lot of foot-rotting, which is a job I dislike as much as dagging. All lame sheep were driven into the woolshed for treatment ... their hoofs pared down and the rot cut out. <i>(1956,Rouseabout Jane,195</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> A little stock work, the drafting and picking of lambs for despatch to the works or sale yards, some help if foot-rotting or dipping was in progress. <i>(1971,Plekhov Place, The,11</i>)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the pruning and treating of decaying sheep's hooves.

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Foot-rotting was a horribly monotonous job after one had been at it for weeks. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,116</i>)

>  <b>MILLS ET AL</b> They involve the use of secateurs for what is commonly known as footrotting, and either shears or machines for dagging. <i>(1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,80</i>)

>  <b>HALL</b> Another unpleasant task is foot-rotting - that is, pruning decaying flesh off a sheep's hooves. The foot-rotting job is a tiring one, with kicks to avoid and every hoof requiring close inspection. [footrotting] <i>(1987,Shepherd's Year,  A,83</i>)

## football

The kauri forest, like the mixed podocarp forest, the sub-tropical rain forest, ... and such-like are terms that come from the botanist and forester, not from the layman - or from the bushman. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,23</i>) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

## Forty Thieves
 
 <i>n.</i> (historical, derogatory) a powerful group of (original) colonial landowners [The 1849 citation below shows that the term was used first in context of the Wellington (Britannia) settlement, and only later in Nelson (and then somewhat differently in Hawke's Bay (1873 citation)). See Orsman for another more recent use in Auckland.]

>  <b>McINTOSH</b> Though his assertions may be discounted the spirit of Saunders's utterances may be taken as a reflection of the attitude of the popular party. In commenting on the fact that the power acquired by `the Original Resident Land Purchasers' Association' was retained long after the Company had ceased to exist, Saunders states `It became a leading and bitter opponent, a dangerous and mischievous class combination, facetiously called `The Nelson Supper Party' and more viciously called also `The Forty Thieves'. This party was very ably led by Dr., afterwards Sir David, Monro, and retained all political power in their own hands until some time after the introduction of representative government into this country. <i>(1940,Marlborough,137</i>) [NOTES: [Saunders in ? Nelson Examiner Oct 1857]]

>  <b>ROLLESTON</b> The notoriety of the defendants [at the 1873 Native Lands Alienation Commission] gave rise to their being called, variously, the twelve apostles (actually only seven were involved in the ownership of twelve shares) or the forty thieves. <i>(1873,Master, The,96,1980 ed.</i>)

>  In the outset of the Company's colonisation scheme, there were certain individuals who, by their disinterestedness in forwarding the establishment of the Company's first and principal settlement, obtained the sobriquet of the Forty Thieves ; and it appears that some individuals forming a portion of the Company's second Colony were anxious to rival the above-named gentlemen in a similar line of conduct. The one set proposed, that no individual holding less than five original land-orders in the settlement, should be eligible to a seat in their self- elected Council for the republican settlement of Britannia, well knowing at the time that none but themselves were qualified under such [a regulation, seeing that they were the holders of ten gratuitous landorders from the Company. The Nelson resident original landpurchasers, on the other hand, propose to exclude all persons who are not, like themselves, resident original purchasers, but who still originally emigrated here, and have become holders of land by purchase from them and the absentee land proprietors, and have embarked their labour and capital for various purposes, thereby promoting the welfare of the settlement, from any right to runs for cattle and sheep upon the waste lands. <i>(Jan 6, 1849,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle</i>) [NOTES: Sourced from Papers Past]

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an allotted portion of land for development by bush settlers [1800s.]

>  <b>WASWO</b> The crowning disappointment for many settlers in New Zealand was the discovery that the forty-acre farms allotted to them were, when cleared and grassed, hopelessly inadequate to support a family. <i>(1996,Farming Progress in NZ 1814-1995,8</i>)



## forty-acre farmer
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> In the eighteen-sixties the Auckland Provincial Council, for instance, promised each immigrant a `free farm' of forty acres ... As one of the `forty acre farmers' said in the House of Representatives thirty years later, he came out because he wanted `a bit of land of his own'. <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,100</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a farmer developing an allotted forty-acre farm under the forty-acre system of the 1800s.

>  <b>SINCLAIR</b> As one of the forty-acre farmers said in the House of Representatives thirty years later, he came out because he wanted 'a bit of land of his own'. <i>(1959,History of New Zealand,100</i>)



## forty-acre man
 
 <i>n.</i> one who receives a (free) forty-acre grant of land [(usu. pl.) (obs. or hist.)]

>  <b>RIDGWAY</b> Will Forty-acre men ruin the country? <i>(1860,Voices from Auckland,48</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> We were lately on the sections of two `forty-acre men.' <i>(1869,Guide to Farming in NZ,42</i>) [NOTES: [? orig. Auckland usage =Canterbury/Otago `cockatoo']]



## forty-acre section
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an allocated portion of land for development into farmland by bush settlers.

>  <b>SILK</b> There they received their two forty-acre sections, of which there was not one square yard of arable land. <i>(1923,History of Puhoi,43</i>)

>  <b>SILK</b> She arrived here with five little children and was given a forty-acre section on the west side of Puhoi. <i>(1923,History of Puhoi,82</i>)

>  <b>MILLER</b> Edie had 200 acres adjoining this block and he and a number of others were keen to get this forty-acre section. <i>(1954,Beyond the Blue Mountains,71</i>)



## forty-acre system
 
 <i>n.</i> [(obs or hist.)]

>  <b>MAY</b> .. the country was a dog-hole ... the forty-acre system a most villainous take-in. <i>(1869,Guide to Farming in NZ,42</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an allocation of land based on units of forty acres.

>  I am no friend to the special settlement system, not being able to see much good that has come of it, that is to say, beyond what would have come of the forty-acre system alone. <i>(Aug 20, 1864,Weekly News,14</i>)

>  <b>KEENE</b> During the 1850s large areas of Crown Land were made available under the 40-acre system, which entitled an adult immigrant on payment of his own fare from Britain, to a grant of 40 acres, plus 40 for his wife, and 20 for each member of his family aged between five and 18 years. Under the 40-acre system the immigrant gave an undertaking to remain in the province and not sell his land for a period of five years, after which time he would be given the freehold title of the land. <i>(1977,To the Northward,128</i>)

>  In New Zealand the forty-acre system has been adopted - a system which has proved most injurious to the country ... <i>(Oct 1866,Weekly News,13</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> The country was a dog-hole .. the forty-acre system a most villainous take-in. <i>(1869,May's Guide to Farming in NZ,42</i>)

>  <b>BARRER</b> "The Britain of the South" with its vaunted climate and scenery attracted them, and especially the forty-acre system .. Disillusionment awaited them. <i>(1939,Brave Days: Pioneer Women of New Zealand,33</i>)



## forty-fives
 
 <i>n.</i> a West Coast card-game [(plural)]

>  <b>WOOD</b> I [the Otago Goldfields Commissioner] cannot describe how welcome that `clay' [pipe] was to me, ... with Dub. [Dublin, an Irish miner], Mexican and Pat, for my companions; the others having gathered round the rough table to enjoy the Irish game of `Forty-fives'. <i>(1875,Waiting for the Mail,32</i>) [NOTES: (`Beside the Billy')]

>  <b>PFAFF</b> Consequently larger numbers grouped themselves outside [the Reefton Courthouse], where they passed the time in playing cards - the favourite game in those days [c.late 1860s] being `forty-fives'. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,110</i>)

>  A background of the haze engendered by tobacco and coal [in Buller pubs] is cards. As staple as beer is, more so is the game of `forty-fives', impossible of definition, where the five of the trump suit beats all other cards and the table gets a thumping. It accumulates all the good-natured interest and noise of which pubs are capable. <i>(1948,NZ Geographer,166</i>) [NOTES: Pascoe `Coal from Buller']

>  In smoky little back parlours [in Westport] friendly little groups meet to play `forty-fives' with uproarious oaths and much heavy thumping of the table. For [100] the uninitiated it may be stated that in this game the five-fingers (the five of the trump suit) beats all other cards. The trump suit order is five, jack, ace, king queen - all other suits begin with the king. Non-trump suits win high in red; low in black. Obviously the ace of diamonds is the lowest card in the pack unless diamonds are trumps, in which case it is the fourth best. The word `obviously' in the preceding sentence is a little optimistic - as the ace of hearts (the Maggy) is always the third best trump. It is credibly reported (a) that the game is of Irish origin (b) that there are no written rules (c) that the game can only be learned by playing it, and (d) it is as characteristic of Westport as whitebait or coal. <i>(1948,Our Own Country,99</i>) [NOTES: Korero Our Own Country]

>  <b>PEARSON</b> [Gloss] Forty-fives: A peculiar card game played on the West Coast, imported originally from Ireland. <i>(1963,Coal Flat,420</i>)

>  <b>CRUMPTON</b> The game played was called Forty-fives, and he could make neither head nor tail of the method of play. There was no money on the table, but a record of games played and won was made on a cribbage board by shifting a match about in the holes. At the conclusion of each game and [sic] a score of forty-five was reached, the losers shouted drinks for the other players, and the cards were shuffled round again. ... The fourth man stood up and excitedly thumped the table with the five of hearts. `I've been waiting for that, twenty-five - one - five, now lead and keep leading.' Play and conversation went on in a similar strain. Dave endeavoured explain the rudiments of the game. `The sequence of the game is highest in red cards and lowest in black. The highest card in the pack is the five of whatever suit turns up, then comes the Jack, and the ace of hearts is always the third highest trump in the pack. But you'll never learn the game looking on, it's too hard to follow. They play four legs to a game which is called a `horse.' Jim's playing a hundred pounds a game, twenty pounds a leg, and twenty pounds at the completion of the game. Then they start again.' <i>(1979,Spencer: the Gold Seeker,41</i>) [NOTES: [West Coast]]

>  <b>BATTYE & EAKIN</b> 45's an Irish card game, scored on a cribbage board, still popular on the West Coast. <i>(1980,Shadow of the Valley,72</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> Old Calamity was an early one-man band of fiddle, horn, cymbals and kettledrums. Gambling was poker of 45s, a diggers' card game from California involving legs, queer suits and Maggie, cries of `Get Jinx!' and `Go for the Doctor!' <i>(1980,Ghost Towns of NZ,127</i>)

>  Above the stage / in the Buffs hung a wicked pair of horns; all the Druids/ did was play Forty-Fives and Euchre. <i>(Sep 28, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61</i>) [NOTES: Jeffrey Paparoa Holman]

## forward
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [stock sales] to present stock for sale.

<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of stock] between store and prime condition, with some ''finishing'' yet to be done.

>  100 2-tooth ewes from up-river, 40 18-month steers, off rough country, 300 forward bush wethers. <i>(Jan 31, 1905,Hawera Star,3</i>)

## forwarding yard/forwarding pen
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The forwarding yards or pens, which are considerably smaller and consequently are useful for dealing with small mobs of sheep, as well as their function of leading up to The crush or forcing pen(s): These are usually one or two long, small pens, frequently tapering at one end, and holding about 50 sheep. They in turn communicate by a two-way gate with the mouth of the Drafting race: This race is long and narrow just wide enough for the sheep to pass through in single file. Its purpose is to divide a mixed flock ... into any required number of smaller mobs, and for this purpose the race is fitted at its exit with one or more drafting gates, which guide the sheep into several <i>(Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7</i>)

>  <b>BOWEN</b> Receiving yards. These must have the capacity to take incoming mobs. They communicate with the forwarding yards, or diamond pens, which are much smaller, and lead up to the crush pens or forcing pens. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,120</i>) [NOTES: [=DIAMOND PEN]]



## fossick
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  v.int. to propect for gold, especially in abandoned claims and diggings; whence fossicker. fossicker n. searcher for gold or other minerals. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),616</i>)

>  fossick vb. Austral. & N.Z. 1. (intr.) to search for gold or precious stones in abandoned workings, rivers, etc. 2. to rummage or search for (something): to fossick around for.  <i>n.</i> a fussy or querulous person; fusspot; troublesome person (often old fossick, young fossick, old (young) devil, etc.) you old fossick =fossie [cf tossle f. tassle] [ca1910 NZ use obsolesc. at least, and possible, influenced by fossil in a similar use (old fossil), and possibly by fuss(-pot).]



 
 <i>v.</i> 1. to search or hunt. 2. to search for gold in abandoned mines, etc. fossicker/

>  <b>THOMPSON</b> Fossicker, fencer, rouseabout, and rabbiter he'd been,/ From Riversdale to Naseby every hamlet he had seen;/ <i>(1909,Ballads about Business,62</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,94</i>)

>  <b>ORBELL</b> In general a frame pack is the most comfortable to pack with provided it fits your body shape. <i>(1952,Comfort & Commonsense in the Bush,16</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> Some became prejudiced about frame packs for instance ... <i>Ibid.</i> 25 I don't think I have come across two cullers with the same view on the subject of equipment. Some become prejudiced about frame packs for instance ... <i>Ibid.</i>27 Frame packs of the Bergen or Canadian type are permitted by the Department, but they must be capable of being used without the frame to provide for emergencies. <i>(1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,24</i>)

>  <i>(1958,Tararua,12/7</i>)

>  She took the backpack off, put the framepack on, staggered a little. The daypack she perched precariously on her shoulders, but she knew she'd need her hands free. <i>(Dec 28, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),B1</i>)

## freeze-out
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> At the end of the evening someone suggested we finish up with a `freeze out' and this was agreed to. The rules of this form of sport were simple. Each player has to have three threepenny pieces and on the first round all put in one threepence. An ordinary poker hand was then dealt and cards were bought as required. There was no betting as all hands were tabled face up and the man with the worst hand was `frozen out'. All he had to do however, was to put in his second threepence and he was in again. After losing three threepences, however, he was frozen out for good. This went on until only two players remained and on the final game the winner took the whole kitty! <i>(1975,Men of the Milford Road,54</i>)

## freezing worker
 
 <i>n.</i> a person who works at a freezing works

>  <b>SLATTER</b> I'd like to see some of these people ... who criticise freezing workers for <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,67</i>)

>  In 1932, wages were cut, and the freezing workers struck throughout the country. The butchers didn't believe that they could be replaced, but when the works reopened it was found that the companies had installed the American chain system, with each worker responsible for only one aspect of the process. The butchers were replaced by the unemployed, who initially made a terrible mess of the carcasses. But in time they became competent process workers, as opposed to the tradesmen who had preceded them. <i>Ibid.</i> 86. The freezing workers sent in a short line-out to meet them: Kennedy and Scott from the New Zealand union, Evans from Auckland and Douglas and Knox from the FOL. <i>(Jul 1986,Metro,76</i>)

>  <b>STEAD</b> Ljuba Panapa was a neighbour, almost a friend, Dalmatian-Catholic of course, but now a young war-widow, which somehow made her more acceptable than she'd seemed as the wife of a Maori freezing worker. <i>(1999,Talking about O'Dwyer,42</i>)

>  If you were to ask 100 New Zealanders "What do you call the people who work on a slaughter chain?", the overwhelming answer would be "freezing workers" - not "meat processing plant workers", "steak manufacturers" or "fresh and wholesome table product converters"! <i>(Dec 1999,North & South,23</i>)

>  In reference to the series of agreements from the Southland Freezing Worker's [sic] Union, the men affected do various kinds of work under different conditions ... <i>(Feb 6, 1908,West Coast Times</i>)

## Frenchman
 
 <i>n.</i> the fish, <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i>

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> FLATHEAD <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> Haast ... Other names for the Flathead are Chinaman and Frenchman, but where these names originated and for what reason I do not know with certainty. One theory is that when Chinamen hawked fish about Dunedin they kept Flatheads for their own consumption, as they preferred them to all other fish. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,286,(2nd edn) ed.</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> FRENCHMAN: see Flathead <i>Ibid.</i> 100 [The Flathead, <i>Kathetostoma</i> sp. is sometimes called Frenchman or Chinaman (presumably because these fishermen sold them in the early Otago days). The Latin translation of the name means roughly `large, perpendicular mouth.' Also known as Spotted Stargazer. <i>Ibid.</i> 100 FRENCHMAN Another name for Flathead. Also known as Chinaman. The latter name apparently derives from the fact that Chinese fish merchants in Dunedin in the early days always kept these fish for their own consumption. Nowadays these fish are more accurately termed Spotted Stargazer. <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,74</i>)



## fresh
 
 <i>n.</i> a rush of water in a river or creek, a flash flood

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> ... the river follows the western hills, and at its freshes overflows the left shore, which was covered with shrublike veronica. <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,1/77</i>)

>  <b>ROCHFORT</b> During the freshes, which occur after heavy rains, the natives come down the river in their canoes by hundreds to see their friends. <i>(1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,26</i>)

>  <b>SEWELL</b> The hot Northwesters melt the Mountain snows, sending down freshes. A fresh was just beginning in the Rangitata as we got to it. <i>(1856,Journal of Henry Sewell,2/221,1980 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> I had to cross the Waimakiriri just after a fresh, ... and I assure you I did not like it. >  <b>BUTLER</b> ...having never crossed any of the rivers on horseback in a fresh, having never seen the Rangitata in a fresh ... it may be imagined that I felt a certain amount of caution to be necessary ... <i>(Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,38,1960 ed.</i>)

>  The ice hockey gives me one, so I front at the nanny goat and see that it's paying a spot. to front at....to go to FRONT (AT) (prison slang) <i>(May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19</i>)



## front bum
 
 <i>n.</i> (coarse slang) the vagina

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>front bum</i> Vagina. A female informant was confronted one Queenstown morning with a cheery request to "show us ya front bum". NZA. <i>(1995,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,45</i>)

>  <b>PLOWMAN</b> front bum: vulgar term for vagina <i>(2002,Great Kiwi Slang</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (coarse slang) a woman (by extension from use for vagina)

>  ...he [John Tamihere] referred to women as "front-bums",lamenting their being promoted to New Zealand's top positions because of their gender. <i>(Apr 11, 2005,Dominion Post,A1</i>)



## front country
 
 <i>n.</i> the country on the plains used for sheep-stations (as distinct from back country nearer the Southern Alps; ? the part of a station nearer the homestead [(mainly Canterbury)]

>  <b>BUTLER</b> Flax and cabbage trees belong more to the front country, they are not so characteristic of the back; the forests too upon the front side of the mountains are well worthy of a description but these things I will reserve for the present. <i>(Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,54</i>)

>  Front country: See Country. <i>(Oct 21, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>JONES</b> No gardeners were kept except on the front country. <i>(1933,Autobiography,72</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Black pine (matai) was used [for fencing] in the front country. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,88</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Mt. Somers station, a `front' country block of about 16,000 acres, lies between Barossa and Winterslow ... <i>(1952,High Country Journey,77</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> These [Canterbury] ranges form a definite barrier between the `front' and `back' country and the inhabitants of each see little of each other. <i>(1970,Glorious Morning,24</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) farmland consisting of foothills, downs and plains which front the east-side of the Southern Alps and high country land [usually relatively accessible to the station or a road.]

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Black pine (matai) was used [for fencing] on the front country but it was not as good as broadleaf, because it rotted away in a few years. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,104</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> In the South Island that country beyond the river gorges is termed back country, as differing from front country which consists of those hills through whose gorges the same rivers wend their way. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,2</i>)

>  <b>Relph</b> To the east of the Main Divide is the 'front country', a series of ranges forming the boundary with the Canterbury Plains. <i>(2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,11</i>)

>  Some of the smaller flocks on front country have almost been wiped out ... <i>(Aug 15, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,5</i>)

>  In Otago also the front country has suffered severely, but some of the mountain stations in the interior must likewise have lost heavily. <i>(Aug 22, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,5</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> The Waimate district has been a Border Leicester stronghold since the early days; these sheep seemed to suit the front country from the very first. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,112</i>)

>  <b>WHEELER</b> In winter, ewes are put on the sunny front country facing the lake, where snow seldom lies. <i>(1971,Historic Sheep Stations SI II,34</i>)

>  <b>DOMINY</b> "Front country" refers to the usually lower-altitude paddocks and blocks used during spring lambing and winter grazing , which are closer to the homestead ... <i>(2001,Calling the Station Home,138</i>)

>  Also sold to dairy farmers were Ngatara Station, Mt Florida Station, and another big property on the front country, whose owners declined to allow it to be named. <i>(Jul 26, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,22</i>)



## front country run
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a pastoral property on the foothills and downs of high country.

>  <b>JONES</b> Most of the front country runs then taken were fully stocked. <i>(1933,Autobiography of an Early Settler,36</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> The front-country runs south of the Rangitata were <i>(1946,Early Canterbury Runs,133</i>)



## front hills
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the eastern foothills adjacent to South Island high country. (See [front country](../F#front-country))

>  <b>MARTIN</b> In 1854 a further ten large runs were established on the remainder of the plains between the Ashburton and Rakaia Rivers; this meant that the entire plains and 'front hills' were taken up. <i>(1990,Forgotten Worker, The,7</i>)



## front lawn
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  "We've fetished the front lawn," says Dann. "Where else could you call a group the Front Lawn and everyone knew what the joke was?" The front Lawn is now unfortunately concreted over, as it were, but in the garden the concept remains "quintessentially Kiwi; it speaks volumes about our culture"... In New Zealand the front lawn has always been an upwardly mowable status symbol.. but mostly.. front lawns are there to keep people away. <i>(Apr 10, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19</i>)



## front lead
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>EVANS</b> Immediately north of the [Waikaka] township a rich layer in the fault-involved older quartz drifts, ... was worked from the surface ... This layer is locally known as the `back lead'. On or near it a shaft was sunk ... but was not utilised for driving-out. ... Somewhere about 1880 ... others drove an inclined drift from point to the southward of the back lead for a distance of 254 feet ... Then they drove horizontally for a short distance and intersected an auriferous ... layer of quartz wash, about 10 feet wide, known as the `front lead'. [fn quotes OED on drift as an excavated passage] <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,4</i>) [NOTES: 1914 P.G. Morgan report Geological Survey Branch 147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4]



## front paddock
 
 <i>n.</i> a paddock that is open to a road and view.

>  If you're going to have an animal in the front paddock, you might as well have a good-looking one. <i>(Oct 21, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,13</i>)

>  <b>PEACHE</b> Front paddock 80 acres/ Upper paddock 50 [do]/ Back paddock 10 [do]/ Middle paddock 20 [do] <i>(Aug 2, 1876,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1876 Aug 2 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 49]

>  <b>BELL</b> ... I will come over tomorrow and help to shift the ewes and lambs into the front paddock - they want a change now. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,149</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> He'd either be in the front paddock, or in the cowbail - or if the cows were all right, he'd be over at the Maize paddock fence. <i>(1978,Elver, The,45</i>)

>  <b>STEWART</b> As I drove up his drive, I noticed a very large mare in the front paddock. <i>(1985,Gumboots and Goalposts,20</i>)



## front porch
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a landing or stage at the front of a dairy factory, on to which produce was loaded and unloaded.

>  <b>TINSLEY</b> The factory stage was the concrete platform, or 'front porch' of the building, only the front being open, with the floor at roughly the same height as most of the vehicles that brought milk from the farms. <i>(1985,Cheese Punchers' Ball, The,41</i>)



## front range
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the side of the South Island mountain range facing east.

>  <b>BUTLER</b> ... in a few years there was not an acre between the sea and the front ranges which was not taken up. <i>(1872,Erewhon,10</i>)



## front run
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> ...to these five were added two shepherds and a stockman from one station ... come over from front runs to attend a general muster of our sheep and cattle. <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,143</i>)



## front side
 
 <i>n.</i> in respect of the Southern Alps, the eastern or Canterbury side

>  <b>STACEY</b> With the horses we were able to go into the front station most weekends. <i>(1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,104</i>)

 <i>v.</i> to appear, confront [(?prison slang)]

<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [fig. use] to push before one, from the transporting of material on the front-end loader of a tractor.

 <i>n.</i> [(station)]

>  frontage n. land on a river or creek. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4</i>)



## frost
 
 <i>n.</i> frostfish, <i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>

>  <b>SORENSON</b> FROSTFISH (a) Scientific name: <i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Frostfish. (c) Other common names: Frosts or Frosties. (d) Principal localities where taken: Cook Strait and East Coast as far as Napier. <i>(1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,25</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [(school)]

## frost flat
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) an extensive area of flat ground, subject to severe frost because of its situation. [ca1900 at least. Specific areas of frost flat are the Rangitaiki, Pureora, and Whirinaki areas of the Central North Island, and parts of Tasman District.]

>  The persistence of frost flat communities at Rangitaiki is being jeopardised by invasive weeds ... <i>(Jan 1990,NZ Journal of Botany,28/225</i>)

>  Threatened plant programmes include wetland, frost flat, forest and coastal species across the area. <i>(Jul 2005,Internet - see Notes</i>) [NOTES: www.jobs.govt.nz/jobs/viewjob.aspx?OpportunityID=22636]

>  <b>Poole & Adams</b> ..<i> Monoao. Shrub reaching 2m .. Branchlets long, slender.</i> Shrub land; especially on so-called 'frost flats' of the volcanic plateau. <i>(1963,Trees and Shrubs,160</i>)

>  Like many unique and special places, frost flats are now firmly on the conservation radar screen. <i>(May 2007,NZ Geographic,44,85 ed.</i>)



## frost lift
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) needle ice, that occurs when damp or wet bare soil or sub-soil is exposed to alternate warming and cooling.

>  <b>MCCASKILL</b> On depleted tussock pastures of the MacKenzie country, frost lift followed by wind erosion became a major Source of soil loss. <i>(1973,Hold This Land,70</i>)

>  <b>MCCASKILL</b> Following on frost lift, blowing by the nor'wester has been responsible for the complete removal of shallow soils down to the clay parent material. <i>(1973,Hold This Land,45</i>)

>  Frost lift pulls the seedlings right out of the ground where they subsequently die of dessication. <i>(May 13, 1982,NZ Farmer,37</i>)



## frost lifting
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the forming of needle ice on exposed high country areas.

>  As a result of burning, tussocks are badly weakened on my country owing to removal of natural humus and the exposure of the surrounding soil to frost-lifting and subsequent erosion. <i>(May 3, 1945,NZ Farmer,11</i>)



## Frostbite
 
 <i>n.</i> class of racing yacht

>  <b>CARTER</b> These two classes, the Akatere and Frostbite, both owe their existence to the efforts of the designer, Mr. J. Brooke, of Devonport, Auckland. <i>Ibid.</i>131 Frostbite class dinghies have been raced in all parts of the North Island, having been transported by car and sailed in Lakes Rotorua, Rotoiti, Okataina, Taupo, Hamilton and Waikaremoana. <i>(1948,Little Ships: NZ's Yachting Fleet,129</i>) [NOTES: 2nd edition]
