>  The Frostbite. In 1938 the Wakatere Boating Club decided to design and build a class similar to the American Frostbite Dinghy, a class in which very "keen" American yachties raced in the winter. <i>(1989,Kohimarama,115</i>)



## frostfish
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  A fine specimen of the frost fish was picked up.. on the North Beach on Friday. <i>(Jun 15, 1917,Wanganui Herald,4</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> [The frost-fish] is only known from from being in frosty weather thrown up by the ocean ... From this circumstance it is known amongst the colonists as the frost-fish. <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,244</i>)

>  [Native or Common Name] Hiku, Frostfish .. [Scientific Name] <i>Lepidopus caudatus</i> <i>Ibid.</i>486 Frostfish only find their way to market in winter time, and are very irregular in supply. <i>(1877,TrNZI,9/485</i>) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

>  <b>SHERRIN</b> FROST FISH (<i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>). ... [30] The frost-fish, or hiku of the Maoris, is esteemed the most delicious fish in New Zealand. It is most commonly found cast up after cold frosty nights on sandy beaches that are exposed to the long roll of ocean swell, and is not in this country obtained by any kind of fishing. <i>Ibid.</i> 300 <i>Lepidopus caudatus</i> Euphrasen Frost-fish, Hiku, or Para. <i>(1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,29</i>)

>  <b>PRESHAW</b> Frost fish, `hiku' of the Maories (Lepidopus Candatus) is esteemed the most delicious fish in New Zealand: these are sometimes found, but only on frosty mornings. <i>(1888,Banking Under Difficulties,177</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

>  Of the edible [pelagic] fishes ... such as the frostfish, barracouta, horse-mackerel, kingfish, dory, warehou, mackerel, and garfish; while only the ling, hake and haddock ... are among those of more southern types ... <i>(1892,NZ Official Handbook,167</i>)

>  <i>7. Portland Island</i>. - Tarakihi, moki, frost-fish, barracouta, king-fish, john-dory, warehou, maomao, parrot-fish, flying-fish, smooth-hound, soldier fish... <i>Ibid.</i> 10. Kaipara Heads. - Frost-fish. <i>(1892,TrNZI,24/203</i>) [NOTES: (Thomson)]

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>Para, n. lepidopus caudatus; frost-fish. </i> <i>(1892,Dictionary of the Maori Language,127</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> ~ name given in Australia and New Zealand to the European <i>Scabbard-fish, Lepidopus caudatus</i>, White. The name is said to be derived from the circumstance that the fish is found alive on New Zealand sea-beaches on frosty nights. It is called the <i>Scabbard-fish</i> in Europe, because it is like the shining white metal sheath of a long sword. <i>Lepidopus</i> belongs to the family <i>Trichiurida</i>; it reaches a length of five or six feet, but is so thin that it hardly weighs as many pounds. It is considered a delicacy in New Zealand. <i>(1898,Austral English,155</i>)

>  <b>BULLER</b> ` The frost-fish ... the most delicately flavoured of all New Zealand fishes, is an inhabitant of deep water, and on frosty sights, owing probably to its air-bladders becoming choked, it is cast up be the surf on the ocean-beach.' And in New Zealand to <i>Carpophaga nova-zealandia, </i> Gmel. (Maori name, <i>Kereru Kuku</i>, or <i>Kukupa.</i>) <i>(1888,Birds of New Zealand,ii./ 51</i>)

>  <b>DRUMMOND & HUTTON</b> The warehou, tarakihi, and gurnet are common in the north, and the moki, butterfish, and frost fish in the south, while the kahawai, hapuku (the groper of Dunedin), blue cod, barracouta, the little sea mullet, sometimes called the herring, and the flat fish are found all round the coast. <i>Ibid.</i> 73 The frost fish, which has a long, silvery body, is usually picked up on the sea beach in the winter weather;... <i>(1902,Nature in NZ,71</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy. <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,94</i>)

## Fun Ho
 
 <i>n.</i> A brand of metal toys, like Dinky Toys, but of initially cruder construction, made originally of lead and then aluminium in Wellington by Harold Underwood in the 1930. In 1945 production moved to New Plymouth and in 1949 to Inglewood where they were made until 1982.

>  A rugged brightly painted Fun Ho! toy in Santa's stocking on Christmas morning was a surprise bringing approving smiles to the faces of Kiwi kids for generations.... Harold (Jack) Underwood made lead slush tops and semiflat figures in his basement as a hobby, unaware that those experiments would become the success that enabled him to resign from the public service and enter the toy-making business... There is an absolutely positively Wellington origin about the distinctive Fun Ho! trademark, too. The design with exclamation nmark was by the late E Mervyn Taylor, a New Zealand arrist who worked in the city at the same time as an illustrator and commercial artist...  <i>n.</i> [see also basket fungus, beech fungus, bracket fungus, brain fungus, bush-fungus, hakeke, strawberry fungus, tobacco pouch usu. Jew's ear fungus, formerly collected, dried and sold to Chinese merchants cf wood fungus]

The New Zealand fungus now under notice (<i>Hirneola polytricha</i>), is well described ... <i>(1891,NZ Journal of Science,1/55</i>)

>  The exports for 1899 were: Wool, 4,819 bales; fungus, 107 sacks; <i>(1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,42</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> At one time Jacobs leased about 2000 acres of the usually useless [Chatham] Tobacco Country. He wanted it for the fungus that grew so abundantly on the kopi trees which formed the main portion of that forest. This he gathered to export to China. The very large, soft circular fungus could also be induced to grow on logs and roots split open and placed in an old tin shed. There copious watering soon covered everything with the huge white growth and all Jacobs had to do was to pull it off the logs and spread it out to dry. A pile a foot or so high would only yield a few handfuls of dry chips. When ready for packing it had to be damped once more to keep it from turning into powder. It never went mouldy because it was a mould to start with. When first sent abroad the Islanders got 4d. a pound for it, later only 2d. Even at that price they stripped the forests and killed the goose. Jacobs seems to have been the only one who attempted to cultivate it. The Chinese used it for soup (it makes a thick, sticky, rather tasteless fluid when boiled), dressing silk and varnish. <i>(1952,Chatham Islands,145</i>)

## funk
 
 <i>v.</i> funking vbl n -->(in marbles) childrens for encroaching your given mark, or not shooting with knuckles on the ground, or otherwise breaking a set rule; to cheat -->ca1930 NZ [(child marble players')]

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899: reference, game of Little Ring] Many heated arguments arose as to who said `everythings' or `nothings' first. If a player's `taw' touched a marble and lay alongside it, the others would shout `knuckle down' just before his turn. ... `Knuckle down' meant that the player had to hold his taw close to the marble attacked and fire it in that very inconvenient position. ... When a boy lost all his marbles at play he was `scat' [?related to skint ?HWO] . ... A `ringer' was a taw which, when fired at the commencement of the game, lodged in the track of the ring itself; that, and knocking a marble out when he `fired' were the perfect shots. ... To fire a shot while holding the hand nearer to the ring than where the taw had lain, was to `funk', an unforgiveable crime. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,176</i>)

>  <b>SCANLAN</b> `Reverend Mother talks of when she used to give you marbles for being a good little boy - pee-wees and agates, and stonies and glassies and a big tor. And once she tried to play with you, and you said she funked because her knuckle was inside the ring.' <i>(1933,Tides of Youth,153</i>)

## funks
 
 <i>n.</i> [(child marble players')]

>  Action terms which refer to the shooting of the marbles are: Knuckle down Stiff, Knee High, Funks [Flunks sic] or Funnicks, Slips, Firsts and Lasts and Forces. ... The term `Knuckle down Stiff' (Taranaki [18]80, Gisborne [18]85, Waitara [18]95) is mentioned by [Lady A.B. Gomme Vo. 1, p.113]. ... As Taranaki [18]80 says, `The term was called out in order to prevent too easy a success against a marble near the ring'. It was less advantageous to fire with the hand on the ground than with the hand elevated, perhaps at `Knee High'. <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,2/769</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,175</i>)

## futtah
 
 <i>n.</i> alteration of Maori whata q.v.

>  Several of them.. have recorded details of their daily lives.. rats that necessitated the erection of futtahs (whatas). <i>(1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,299</i>) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a station store [alteration of Maori whata.]

>  <b>THORNTON</b> Acland has defined the term "futtah" as a "station store built on high posts to keep rats and mice out. Both name and design are borrowed from the Maori." In the South Island especially this name, a corruption from "whata" was quite common. ..E S Elwell, who refers to the structure at Papakaio near Oamaru as "the futtah, or store, weatherboarded, and with a shingle roof...." <i>(1986,NZ Heritage of Farm Buildings,245</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> Futtah: A food store built on high posts so as to deny entry to rats and mice. This system was learned from the Maoris and the word is a corruption of their whata. Pronunciation has also corrupted into watty. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,34</i>)

>  <b>THORNTON</b> One of the very few survivors of the true futtah raised high on piles is that of Orari Gorge station.. The futtah is clad in weatherboards.. <i>(1986,NZ Heritage of Farm Buildings,246</i>)
